title: The base expectations for classes REQUIRE tanks to be unsatisfying to play
body:
Marksmen: Do nothing (mostly) but ranged dps, need to position far from enemy carries, can often only hit tanks - they absolutely have to be able to shred tanks or they're pretty much unplayable when they're tuned right (which they aren't right now).

Skirmishers: Squishy melee dps champions. Specifically designed with the intention of being able to melt any class, basically unplayable if they can't shred through tanks quickly because against coordinates play tanks are all they can hit.

Juggernauts: Low mobility sustained burst, have no way past he frontline, are designed around  the assumption that they can _burst_ through durability.l, otherwise they are useless. Their _fucking core item as a class makes tanks less tanky_

DPS Mages: this isn't really a unified class under riot's terms, but champs like Cass and Karthus and Zyra are designed to have mediocre to poor backline access, no defensive tools, and backloaded damage, which means, once again, they have to be able to melt through tanks to be playable. They were actually so overtuned against tanks that riot gave tanks an item specifically to counter them (instead of just returning the interaction, because riot) but then made it garbage (again: because riot).

That right there is four classes which BY DESIGN, without anything else, as just part of the fundamental assumptions integral to their design, HAVE to do be able to kill tanks quickly, when the whole point of playing a tank is that you want to live for a long time.

That's not counting divers, which also love black cleaver, for some reason often get attack-speed steroids and heavy repeating damage and have to by their nature be durable enough to ignore a tank's damage, burst mages which can't easily kill a tank on their own but can heavily chunk them, and supports whose need to be effective enough to protect their adcs from skirmishers and divers, and therefore just sort of automatically remove the possibility of an adc ever being affected by a tank in any way whatsoever in the late game.

Seeing as riot has decided that tanks should never be able to duel or waveclear, eliminating them from the toplane, and that they shouldn't have meaningfully clearapeeda or jungle sustain (except Zac and Sejuani) making the jungle feel like shit for them, I'm at a loss as to when Riot wants tanks to feel like they're actually doing something.

And no, band-aid fixes like {{item:3193}} really don't cut it.

replies.body:
I think the issue here isn't so much that all of these classes need to kill tanks quickly, so much as it is that many of these classes need to kill tanks quickly... or else they die before being able to contribute. Skirmishers especially are squishy frontliners with situational defenses who will die the moment they're locked down and focused in a teamfight, and both juggernauts and battle mages, who can only become as tanky as tanks (they're usually squishier) will also die quickly when tanks get shredded. The one outlier here is marksmen, who can more or less spend all the time they want shooting enemies from a distance when protected adequately.

The thing is, tanks dying too quickly is a problem pretty specific to League at this point. Games like HotS, Smite and Dota 2 have tremendously durable tanks, while also having viable equivalents to melee carries, juggernauts and DPS mages on the side at all levels of play. Part of the reason why they succeed is because front lines tend to be a little more porous (most players have a chance of affecting the back line if they play their cards right), but also because the overall amount of damage in the game is at a level where players can fight tanks, take a bit of heat, and still survive for long enough to make an impact in combat, unless they mess up spectacularly. By contrast, damage in League is so high that most champions effectively cannot survive long enough to operate at a natural pace, which is why light fighters, who are supposed to expose themselves to their enemies, only work when they can burst down the back line while avoiding most of their damage.

Because of this, I think part of the solution should be to actually tone down damage overall, or at least prevent champions from snowballing too quickly to a point where their damage becomes excessive. Creating a front line where champions, including members of squishier classes, can operate without needing either excessive burst or too many defenses, would allow tanks to be tankier without shutting down their targets altogether. I get that it's imperative to avoid noodle fights, but we're way past that stage at this point, especially when most new releases are given some form of innate anti-tank damage.

Imo this is an issue that popped out the moment life steal and self sustain became a spread and powerful thing.

That is the point when burst damage had to become "oneshotting" because the level of self heals became so high that anything that survived longer than 2 seconds after a burst came back in the fight with all the hp/defenses needed to kill who had fewer than this (which usually are the mages) GW didn't help either as the only item capable of applying it without bringing the enemies in a near death state is an AD item.

I completely agree, one of the reasons why damage is so high overall right now is because life steal itself is so powerful that its users either die near-instantly, or out-heal the weaker follow-up damage that gets thrown at them, so damage needs to be adjusted so that the first outcome happens more often. High life steal also means marksmen and light fighters end up with extremely high DPS (which is why it's often in burst-per-second territory now), and the end result is an environment where the outcome of a fight is more or less determined within the first few seconds, and is often heavily dependent on stats rather than outplays, which doesn't benefit anyone and is the reason why entire classes feel out of whack right now.

I think the motive behind increasing damage and weakening tanks has been to increase the pace of matches, but while they've been ending faster overall, the game's pacing often feels unnatural, and too snowbally for one side to enjoy it. I also don't think it's worth sacrificing the fantasies of entire classes, as games like HotS and Smite have even shorter average game lengths while still having tanky tanks. If League is to increase its pace, it's going to have to do so through deeper structural changes, rather than "quick fixes" to key numbers that achieve the intended goal at far too high a cost.

In theory, you're right.

In practice, the play patterns of tanks require them to allow themselves to be vulnerable to all and any damage the enemy team cares to throw their way for extended periods of time.

I remember when I joined, in season 2, the general fight pattern for an engage tank was to dive into the enemy team, then sit as close to the enemy squishiest as possible, using your abilities on cooldown. If you died early or got cc-locked, then you probably won the fight, because the enemy team wasted too much damage on you.

Now the play pattern is to dive in, frantically trying to get off your rotation while being chain-cced, then flash out and wait for cooldowns because you'll die before they come up otherwise, then dive in a second time and probably die.

The prevailing philosophy (among pros and high level players too, not just my shit-tier games) was that thornmail and GA, while powerful, were poor purchases as they discouraged focus and you _wanted_ to be focused.

Then I remember when thornmail was nerfed because tanks were buying it to discourage the adc from just autoing them down when they fought (which Randuins used to prevent) and riot wanted ADCs to be able to safely auto tanks. That's why the slow was taken off tonight passive, randuins and frozen heart have repeatedly had their attack speed slow nerfed, and ga was changed to make it much weaker on tanks. Tanks were so desperate for late game durability, they were buying ga.

I also remember that riot tried to balance tanks around the time of the game when they're supposed to "Come online". First the idea was that they are strong mid and late game, because if they were actually tank in the laning phase it wouldn't be fair to players that wanted to kill them. That's why they eventually got balanced around hiding and waveclearing instead of actually 
fighting, because it was deemed unfair for them to be hard to kill when laning.

Then it got deemed bad that they were able to survive so long in the late game, because it made games too slow and besides ADCs had been patiently waiting all game to be strong and it wasn't fair for it to be hard for them to kill a champion with five armor items and a kit designed to make them hard for ADCs to kill without doing much else. 

Then it got deemed unfair that they were using their waveclear base damages to actually fight people in the midgame, because a tank focused around the midgame shouldn't be able to dual an adc based around the late game in the midgame, especially when the ADCs team tried to dump damage on them instead of using cc to peel and got upset when they could burst the tank. So their damage got nerfed, and their midgame tankiness got gutted in favor of making them much tankier late game when all the damage threats that shred through any amount of tankiness are present and fully scaled.

Since tanks had no ability to fight people early or midgame, they started building double dorans so that their weakened waveclear could actually work and sitting under their tower, only sticking their heads out to delete waves. The dorans also helped with their shit-tier Mana sustain. Unfortunately, that was "uninteractive" because a class that was tuned for seasons and seasons to be unable to actually fight people was refusing to actually fight people so champions like Darius and riven and renekton weren't able to get the 3 free early kills necessary snowball a win against a tank top. So dorans were nerfed.

Now tanks are just kinda accepting that they will be low-income adc-bitches like the support of old and buying support items so that they can maintain their 48% winrates. And we'll all know that riot will respond by being support items, because tanks aren't supposed to do anything beyond engage and immediately die or peel for ADCs.

OP was already too long and poorly organized, but here are some more thoughts in no particular order:

* Riot has made it clear that they don't want tanks to be propped up by consistent low-cost play cc like malph, amumu, and old sej ulties. This sounds great until you realize that that means they want engage to be consistently negated at high levels of play by Thresh Flay or Janna Q (in the case of champs like Amumu or Zac) or body blocking/sidestepping (in the case of champs like Sion or Sejuani) there is no counter counterplay against this, you just never get to hit a competent backline.

* Tying into supports, Riot wants supports to be just as impactful as everyone else, but not have "selfish power) such as damage or tank stats. This means that adcs will never have to even acknowledge a tank's damage ever again, as tanks aren't meant to have strong damage and supports basically have to have huge heals and shields.

* Sion is held up as the ideal tank, but his ability to lane is entirely propped up by his e, a poke-mage ability, and late game he is relegated to ulting in, soaking some ults, and dying; or peeling for his adc.

* What all this means is that a tank basically gets to do one of two things: Tickle and cc the enemy frontline (other tanks who don't really care or juggernauts who just use you to stack up damage and burst you out) or sit back and peel for your adc, completely wasting your tank stats in favor of being a shittier Janna. Exciting.

The problem is, when you have tanks that don't have weak damage, you end up with super cancerous unkillable assassins that jump into the back line and kill enemy squishies while CCing them and tanking the rest of their team.

I think it's hard to have a "tank" class that feels satisfying for both sides, just thanks to their core concepts - "have cc" and "be hard to kill".  I can see your points, but the alternatives can be just as bad.

>The problem is, when you have tanks that don't have weak damage, you end up with super cancerous unkillable assassins that jump into the back line and kill enemy squishies while CCing them and tanking the rest of their team.

The solution to this is to make everybody tankier off of just base stats and allow Tanks much more extreme tankiness as the game goes on. At this point you can give tanks DPS without them feeling oppressive and create a world where a tank will rend down an ADC over the course of several seconds. It would also allow you to differentiate Assassins and Fighters more by giving Fighters the baseline DPS required to kill a Tank but minimal burst and giving Assassins burst capable of killing a carry but minimal DPS.

I also don't really have much of a problem when either of these 2 classes wreck tanks (granted they do tend to wreck them a bit too fast for my liking, but I digress).  The real crux of the problem isn't that juggernauts and adcs counter tanks, it is that basically every single class has an extremely strong and effective answer to tanks (as the OP pointed out).  Not only that, but all these classes seem to _require_ that level of power to even function with a modicum of success (or at least, it seems that Riot _believes_ that they do, whether they actually require that capability is highly suspect imho).

Assassins shouldn't have any answer to tanks except "try to catch someone squishier and kill *them* before the tank can interfere".  If an assassin blows their combo on a tank they deserve to be useless for the rest of the fight and/or die.

Ditto assassin-mages and burst-combo mages like Veigar and Syndra, and probably burst fighters like Riven and Kha'zix.

"You picked the wrong person to throw all your burst at" should totally be a thing that can cost you a teamfight, and tanks should be that wrong person.

To stop running in the direction of "tanks shouldn't deal damage" and allow tanks damage to exist on a continuous line between low damage tanks like Braum and Alistar and near bruiser level damage at the high end. It makes sense for these low damage/high bulk support tanks to have this much CC, it doesn't make sense for champs like Sejuani, Galio, Poppy and Zac to have CC on almost every ability.

One of the games I've been playing more often now is terraria, and I feel they have a decent balance going on there, with a favour to melee champs. The point is terraria has its own way to deal with the melee-ranged discrepancy. All attacks can miss, every one of them, meaning there are items that have good ranged dps, but they have the capacity to be dodged and miss their target. Melee items have this too, a ranged attack that has a cooldown but can also be dodged. The only exception to this rule are chlorophyte bullets which are significantly weaker than other types of bullets because they have a small homing range.

The point is, if league had its sustained dps champions damage placed in an avoidable manner, the game could potentially be balanced a lot easier.
